title: Qadi Husayn Maybudi
text:
Qadi Kamal al-Din Husayn ibn Mu'in al-Din Ali Maybudi (), better known as Qadi Husayn Maybudi (), was an Iranian scholar and "<a href="qadi">qadi</a>" (judge) in the city of <a href="Yazd">Yazd</a> under the <a href="Aq%20Qoyunlu">Aq Qoyunlu</a>. He was executed in 1504 after having participated in a failed revolt against the <a href="Safavid%20Iran">Safavid</a> <a href="shah">shah</a> (king) <a href="Ismail%20I">Ismail I</a> ().
Biography.
Born in 1449, Maybudi was presumably a native of the city of <a href="Maybud">Maybud</a> in southern Iran, rather than the neighbouring city of <a href="Yazd">Yazd</a>. The area was then part of the <a href="Timurid%20Empire">Timurid Empire</a>. He belonged to an affluent and influential family of aristocratic origin. He was the son of Khwaja Mu'in al-Din Ali, a prominent philanthropist and <a href="vizier">vizier</a> of Yazd. At a young age, Maybudi left for Shiraz to study under prominent scholars such as <a href="Jalal%20al-Din%20Davani">Jalal al-Din Davani</a> (died 1503). He was executed in 1504 after having participated in a failed revolt against the <a href="Safavid%20Iran">Safavid</a> <a href="shah">shah</a> (king) <a href="Ismail%20I">Ismail I</a> (). He was survived by at least one of his sons, Mirza Abd al-Rashid al-Munajjim.
